work.p: This manuscript is a partial draft of the sixth poem in the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass, ultimately entitled "Faces." The corresponding lines read: "The same wait to clear the rubbish from the fallen tenement; / And I shall look again in a score or two of ages, / And I shall meet the real landlord perfect and unharmed, every inch as good as myself" (1855, p. 84).

a machine readable transcription

Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: This manuscript was likely written between 1850 and 1855 when Whitman was composing his first edition of Leaves of Grass. It is a partial draft of the sixth poem in that edition, entitled "Leaves of Grass," eventually entitled "Faces."

bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: [waited their due time to clear the rubbish]
bibl.orgName: The Walt Whitman Collection, Harry Ransom Humanities Research Center, The University of Texas at Austin
bibl.note: Transcribed from a digital image of the original manuscript.
Draft poetic lines are written on the back of the leaf.

lg.l:
he same , waited their due turn to clear the rubbish
from the fallen house tenement,
And I shall am to look again in a score or two of ages

And I shall meet the real landlord when
stable built
